perturbation.original_text: (a) Payments. In consideration for provision of the Content and all rights granted hereunder, Emdeon hereby agreed to pay WebMD the amounts set forth on Exhibit B of this Agreement. All amounts payable shall be due be due thirty (30) days after the receipt of WebMD's invoice.
perturbation.changed_text: (a) Payments. In consideration for provision of the Content and all rights granted hereunder, Emdeon hereby agreed to pay WebMD the amounts set forth on Exhibit B of this Agreement. All amounts payable shall be due fifteen (15) days after the receipt of WebMD's invoice.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment terms to 15 days contradicts standard business practices and potentially state-level prompt payment laws which often allow for a longer payment period. Many states have prompt payment laws that specify timelines for payments, and mandating a 15-day turnaround can be problematic depending on the specific jurisdiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Prompt Payment Laws (example: varies by state, often provides for 30 days or more for invoice payment)

perturbation.original_text:
(c) Requirements. During the term of this Agreement and for so long as such information remains a trade secret under applicable law, neither party will, except as otherwise expressly directed by the other

-5-

Source: WEBMD HEALTH CORP., S-1/A, 9/8/2005

party, use, copy, or disclose, or permit any unauthorized person access to, any of the other party's Trade Secrets, except as expressly permitted herein and necessary for accomplishment of activities required hereby. During the term of this Agreement and for a period of two (2) years after termination hereof, neither party will use, copy, or disclose, or permit any unauthorized person access to, any of the other party's Confidential Information, except as expressly directed by such party or as permitted herein.
perturbation.changed_text:
(c) Requirements. During the term of this Agreement and for so long as such information remains a trade secret under applicable law, neither party will, except as otherwise expressly directed by the other

-5-

Source: WEBMD HEALTH CORP., S-1/A, 9/8/2005

party, use, copy, or disclose, or permit any unauthorized person access to, any of the other party's Trade Secrets, except as expressly permitted herein and necessary for accomplishment of activities required hereby. During the term of this Agreement and for a period of ninety (90) days after termination hereof, neither party will use, copy, or disclose, or permit any unauthorized person access to, any of the other party's Confidential Information, except as expressly directed by such party or as permitted herein.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period for Confidential Information to 90 days after termination is likely to be considered unreasonably short, particularly for sensitive business data. This contradicts the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing, as it allows for rapid exploitation of confidential information post-termination. Trade secrets are protected for as long as they remain trade secrets, regardless of contract termination.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Trade Secret Laws (e.g., Uniform Trade Secrets Act - varies by state); Implied Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing

perturbation.original_text: (a) Notices. All material notices and other communications required or permitted under this Agreement shall be in writing and notices will be deemed given three (3) days after they are sent by first class mail, return receipt requested, and one (1) day after they are sent by overnight courier or upon receipt if delivered by hand delivery, to the receiving party's address as set forth in the first paragraph above, or to such other address that the receiving party may have provided in writing to the other party for purposes of receiving notices as provided in this Section.
perturbation.changed_text: (a) Notices. All material notices and other communications required or permitted under this Agreement shall be in writing and notices will be deemed given upon dispatch regardless of delivery or receipt confirmation to the receiving party's address as set forth in the first paragraph above, or to such other address that the receiving party may have provided in writing to the other party for purposes of receiving notices as provided in this Section.
perturbation.explanation: Stating that notices are deemed given upon dispatch, regardless of delivery or receipt confirmation, can contradict legal requirements for proper notification, especially in cases involving legal disputes or contract termination. Courts generally require proof of receipt or a reasonable attempt to deliver the notice. This change removes the assurance of receipt, potentially violating due process or fair notice requirements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Due Process requirements under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments (U.S. Constitution); Contract Law principles of proper notification
